rt_sigprocmask is used by libc::abort during a panic to block and unblock signals
rt_sigreturn is needed in case a fault does occur, so that the signal handler can return. Otherwise we get stuck in a fault loop.
sigaltstack is used by Rust stdlib to remove alternative signal stack during thread teardown.
getrandom is used by aws-lc library which we consume in virtio-rng

Used by the VirtIO balloon device and by musl for some customer workloads. It is also used by aws-lc during random number generation. They setup a memory page that mark with MADV_WIPEONFORK to be able to detect forks. They also call it with -1 to see if madvise is supported in certain platforms.
Used by the VirtIO pmem device to sync the file content with the backing file.
Used by the VirtIO balloon device
Used for reading the timezone in LocalTime::now()
Used by rust's stdlib, particularly when creating a diff snapshot of a VM with ~16 GB of memory
Used by io_uring for mapping the queues
rt_sigaction is used by libc::abort during a panic to install the default handler for SIGABRT
Called to open the vsock UDS
tkill is used by libc::abort during a panic to raise SIGABRT
Used to kick vcpus
Needed for rate limiting and metrics
Used to make vsock UDS nonblocking

libkrun: glibc 2.26+ maps open() to openat(AT_FDCWD, ...)
libkrun: glibc 2.33+ maps stat/fstat to newfstatat
libkrun: modern file stat (used by glibc 2.38+)
libkrun: modern readlink (glibc uses readlinkat)
libkrun: modern unlink (glibc uses unlinkat)
libkrun: modern thread creation (glibc 2.34+, used for vCPU threads)
libkrun: legacy thread/process creation
libkrun: close range of file descriptors (glibc 2.34+)
libkrun: create epoll instance
libkrun: epoll wait (used alongside epoll_pwait)
libkrun: memory protection changes for guest RAM regions

libkrun: listen on socket

libkrun: restartable sequences (glibc 2.35+)

automatically issued by the kernel when specific timing-related syscalls (e.g. nanosleep) get interrupted by SIGSTOP
Go runtime (gvproxy): glibc maps open() to openat(AT_FDCWD, ...) on modern x86_64
Go runtime (gvproxy): timer and sleep operations
Go runtime (gvproxy): memory protection changes for GC and stack growth
Go runtime (gvproxy): thread creation by Go scheduler
Go runtime (gvproxy): creates epoll instance for Go netpoller
Go runtime (gvproxy): bind socket for network proxy
Go runtime (gvproxy): listen on socket for network proxy
Go runtime (gvproxy): get socket address
Go runtime (gvproxy): set socket options
Go runtime (gvproxy): get process ID
Go runtime (gvproxy): get thread ID
Go runtime (gvproxy): thread group kill for signal delivery
Go runtime (gvproxy): positioned read
Go runtime (gvproxy): get/set resource limits
Go runtime (gvproxy): CPU affinity for Go scheduler
Go runtime (gvproxy): robust futex list for pthread
Go runtime (gvproxy): set thread ID pointer for clone
Go runtime (gvproxy): architecture-specific thread state for TLS setup
Go runtime (gvproxy): check file access permissions
Go runtime (gvproxy): get system info
Go runtime (gvproxy): restartable sequences for performance
Go runtime (gvproxy): signal handler registration for all signals (ge 0 = match any signal number)
Go runtime (gvproxy): file deletion

Go runtime + libkrun: allow all socket domains/types (ge 0 = match any). Needed because Go runtime and libkrun use various combinations of AF_UNIX/AF_INET/AF_INET6 with different flags (SOCK_STREAM, SOCK_CLOEXEC, SOCK_NONBLOCK).
Go runtime + libkrun: allow all fcntl commands (ge 0 = match any). Go uses F_GETFD/F_GETFL/F_SETFL; libkrun may use others.
Go runtime (gvproxy): goroutine stack allocation
Go runtime (gvproxy): modern file stat (replaces fstat/newfstatat)
Go runtime (gvproxy): general memory allocation (ge 0 = match any flags, needed for MAP_DROPPABLE, PROT_NONE reservation, etc.)

Go runtime + KVM init: allow all ioctl request codes (ge 0 = match any). Needed because TSYNC applies one filter to all threads, but libkrun init requires 28+ KVM ioctls and Go runtime uses TCGETS2/FIONBIO/FIOCLEX.
Go runtime (gvproxy) + libkrun: file descriptor duplication
Go runtime (gvproxy): file descriptor duplication
Go runtime (gvproxy): directory creation
Go runtime (gvproxy): file stat operations
Go runtime (gvproxy): I/O multiplexing
Go runtime (gvproxy): thread setup (PR_SET_NAME, etc.)
Go runtime (gvproxy): read symbolic links (e.g. /proc/self/exe)
Go runtime (gvproxy): precise sleep (glibc maps nanosleep to clock_nanosleep)
Go runtime (gvproxy): positioned write

args.comment: KVM_KVMCLOCK_CTRL. We call this after pausing vCPUs to avoid soft lockups in the guest.
